title: Feb 2025 FQE - Paediatrics
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine and Surgery - Paediatrics (February 2025). Includes MCQs, SAQs, and Clinical Cases.

questions.question: A mother comes to you with a 4-month-old baby who is unable to support the neck. The baby has had convulsions on and off since birth. On examination, you find head lag with tonic limbs. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture suggests Cerebral Palsy (CP). Key features: Convulsions since birth (neonatal seizures are a risk factor), unable to support neck at 4 months (motor delay), and 'tonic limbs' indicating hypertonia/spasticity. While birth asphyxia is a cause, the clinical diagnosis is CP.
questions.hint: Consider the combination of motor delay, tone abnormality, and history of seizures.

questions.question: A 2-day-old baby is brought to you with history of yellowness of the eyes and body that seem to be increasing each hour. You request for bilirubin level and find it elevated. How will you manage?
questions.explanation: Jaundice appearing within the first 24-48 hours (pathological jaundice) that is increasing rapidly indicates a high risk of kernicterus. Exchange transfusion is the emergency management for rapidly rising severe hyperbilirubinemia to wash out antibodies and bilirubin.
questions.hint: Rapidly rising bilirubin in the first 48 hours is a medical emergency.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of correct positioning during breast feeding?

options.text: More areola seen above than below
Baby's body straight and close to the mother

questions.explanation: The question asks for a sign of POSITIONING, not attachment. Positioning signs include: Baby's body straight, head and body in line, and body close to mother. Options A, B, and C describe attachment.
questions.hint: Distinguish between how the baby is held (positioning) vs how the baby latches (attachment).

questions.question: A PP1 pupil presents to you with a generalized maculopapular rash, fever, cough, running nose and red eyes. A playmate had similar symptoms. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation is classic for Measles: Prodrome of Fever + The '3 Cs' (Cough, Coryza, Conjunctivitis) followed by a generalized maculopapular rash.
questions.hint: Look for the '3 Cs' in the symptoms.

questions.question: A HIV positive child is due for immunization. He is 6 weeks now and has not had any immunization, the mother says he is not sick. Which immunization will you give today to catch up?
questions.explanation: BCG is given to HIV-exposed or infected infants unless they have clinical signs of symptomatic HIV (AIDS). Since the mother reports he is 'not sick' (asymptomatic) and missed the birth dose, BCG is indicated as catch-up.
questions.hint: Which vaccine is typically given at birth but can be given later if asymptomatic?

questions.question: A 3-year-old presents to you with fever, vomiting and chills, a blood slide for malaria parasite is positive. You gave her AL (Artemether-Lumefantrine) but no response after 5 days. What will be your second line treatment?
questions.explanation: In Kenya, the recommended second-line treatment for uncomplicated malaria treatment failure (within 14 days of AL) is Dihydroartemisinin-Piperaquine (DHA-PPQ).
questions.hint: Think of the oral alternative used for treatment failure in uncomplicated malaria.

questions.question: A 2-year-old presents to you with cough, night sweats and weight loss. He is HIV positive, Gene Xpert is also positive for TB. What will be the HIV WHO clinical staging?
questions.explanation: Pulmonary Tuberculosis (PTB) is classified as WHO Clinical Stage III in children with HIV.
questions.hint: Pulmonary TB falls into the third stage; Extra-pulmonary is fourth.

questions.question: A child presents to you with diarrhea not blood stained, foul smelling, mucoid associated with abdominal pains. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: Amoebiasis is characterized by foul-smelling, mucoid stools and abdominal pain. Shigellosis typically presents with bloody diarrhea. Cholera presents with rice-water stool.
questions.hint: Foul-smelling and mucoid stools are key descriptors here.

questions.question: A child is brought to you with dyspnea, cough and fever. On examination you find him grunting, head nodding, cyanosis and chest in drawing. What will be your first line antibiotics for management of this patient?
questions.explanation: The child has Severe Pneumonia (Danger signs: Cyanosis, Grunting, Head nodding). First-line inpatient treatment is IV Benzylpenicillin (Crystalline Penicillin) and Gentamicin.
questions.hint: Think of the standard first-line IV combination for severe pneumonia.

questions.question: You are called to resuscitate a newborn. You decide to give oxygen, what will be the best delivery method to achieve 80-90% oxygen?
questions.explanation: To deliver high concentrations of oxygen (80-90%+) to a spontaneously breathing patient, a non-rebreather mask with a reservoir bag is the most effective method.
questions.hint: This device has a reservoir bag to maximize oxygen concentration.

questions.question: A 6-month-old presents with ear discharge, she often pulls the ear and cries a lot. On examination you find ear discharge. How will you manage?

options.text: Refer to ENT for ear irrigation

questions.explanation: Management of Acute Otitis Media with discharge involves local cleansing (wicking/dry mopping) and oral antibiotics (Amoxicillin is first-line).
questions.hint: Standard treatment for AOM involves oral antibiotics and local hygiene.

questions.question: A pregnant woman had folic acid deficiency. What will be the expected effect on the baby?
questions.explanation: Folic acid deficiency in early pregnancy is strongly associated with Neural Tube Defects (NTDs), the most common of which is Spina Bifida.
questions.hint: This is a neural tube defect preventable by pre-conception supplementation.

questions.question: A 3-week-old baby is brought to you convulsing. What drug will you administer as a loading dose?
questions.explanation: Phenobarbitone is the first-line anticonvulsant for neonatal seizures. The loading dose is 20 mg/kg IV.
questions.hint: Diazepam is generally avoided in neonates; think of the barbiturate used.

questions.question: Which Cyanotic heart disease presents with cyanosis at birth?
questions.explanation: Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) typically presents with severe cyanosis immediately at birth due to parallel circulation. TOF usually presents later.
questions.hint: This condition involves the aorta and pulmonary artery being swapped.

questions.question: A child presents to you with a murmur, he had sore-throat and migratory polyarthritis which was treated as an outpatient. On examination you find a murmur at the apex. What valvular lesion do you suspect?
questions.explanation: History suggests Rheumatic Fever. Rheumatic Heart Disease most commonly affects the Mitral valve. A murmur at the apex is characteristic of mitral valve lesions (Stenosis or Regurgitation).
questions.hint: Rheumatic fever most commonly damages the valve located at the apex.

questions.question: Which one is a component of DUKE Major criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis?

options.text: Positive blood culture and heart involvement

questions.explanation: Duke's Major Criteria include: 1. Positive Blood Culture for typical organisms, 2. Evidence of Endocardial Involvement (Echocardiogram findings).
questions.hint: Think about direct evidence of the infection in the blood or heart structure.

questions.question: Which type of fluid will you give to a child diagnosed of malnutrition and severe dehydration?
questions.explanation: In severe acute malnutrition (SAM), standard IV fluids or ORS are dangerous due to sodium load. ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition) is the fluid of choice, given orally/NGT.
questions.hint: Malnourished children need a specific rehydration solution with less sodium and more potassium.

questions.question: According to ETAT, which of the following is an emergency sign?
questions.explanation: Severe dehydration is an Emergency sign (Circulation). Pallor and Burns are Priority signs. 'History of convulsions' is less urgent than active convulsions or severe dehydration.
questions.hint: Emergency signs usually involve Airway, Breathing, Circulation, or Coma/Convulsions.

questions.question: A preterm needs resuscitation at birth. Which group require continuous positive airway pressure prophylaxis (CPAP)?
questions.explanation: Grunting is a sign of respiratory distress and an attempt to maintain lung volume. CPAP provides this pressure externally and is the standard prophylaxis/treatment for preterms with distress.
questions.hint: Which sign indicates the baby is trying to create their own positive pressure?

questions.question: A child is brought to you wheezing, on examination you find head nodding and cyanosis. He uses a salbutamol inhaler. What will be your first step in management?
questions.explanation: Cyanosis indicates hypoxia, a life-threatening emergency. The first step in ABC resuscitation is to correct hypoxia by giving oxygen.
questions.hint: Treat the hypoxia first.

questions.question: A child presents to you with history of passing little dark urine, his blood pressure is 150/100 mmhg, facial puffiness that improves as the day progresses. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: The classic triad of Hematuria (dark urine), Hypertension, and Edema points to Acute Glomerulonephritis (Nephritic Syndrome).
questions.hint: Dark urine and high blood pressure are the key differentiators from Nephrotic syndrome.

questions.question: Which of the following is a laboratory characteristic feature of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Hypoalbuminemia (<2.5g/dL) is a defining laboratory criteria caused by massive proteinuria. Edema is clinical. Hyperlipidemia is secondary.
questions.hint: The loss of protein in urine leads to low levels of this protein in the blood.

questions.question: You are asked to give advice to a mother of a newborn on cord care of her baby. What will be your advice?
questions.explanation: Current guidelines recommend applying 4% Chlorhexidine digluconate daily to the umbilical cord stump to prevent infection.
questions.hint: Surgical spirit is no longer recommended; think of the gel used in modern kits.

questions.question: A 3-year-old weighing 15kgs presents with weak thready pulse and cold clammy extremities. He had diarrhea and vomiting for two days. How much fluid will you give immediately?
questions.explanation: The child is in Shock. Treatment is 20-30ml/kg bolus. WHO Plan C often uses 30ml/kg in the first 30 mins. 15kg x 30ml/kg = 450ml.
questions.hint: Calculate 30ml/kg for the initial bolus.

questions.question: A 20kg child presents to you with fever, convulsions and hemoglobin of 4g/dl. What drug and dose will you give if the blood slide is positive for malaria parasites?
questions.explanation: Severe malaria treatment is IV Artesunate. Dosing: <20kg gets 3.0mg/kg; 20kg+ gets 2.4mg/kg. The source key marks 60mg (3.0mg/kg) as correct, treating 20kg as the cutoff for the higher pediatric dose.
questions.hint: Severe malaria requires IV treatment. Calculate based on 3mg/kg.

questions.question: You are called to casualty for a patient who presents to you in sickle cell crisis. What will be your first step?
questions.explanation: Hydration is critical to dilute the blood, reduce viscosity, and reverse the sickling process causing the vaso-occlusive crisis.
questions.hint: Reversing the dehydration is key to stopping the sickling.

questions.question: A 5 Year old boy is brought to you with history of bleeding after circumcision. The mother reports of bleeding for long after an I.M injection. How will you confirm your impression?
questions.explanation: The history suggests a coagulation disorder like Hemophilia. A Coagulation screen (PT/PTT) is the confirmatory test.
questions.hint: This is a bleeding disorder affecting clotting factors.

questions.question: A 6 year old is brought to you with an abdominal mass that was coincidentally found during bathing. It is fast growing and you suspect a tumor. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: Nephroblastoma (Wilms Tumor) typically presents as an asymptomatic abdominal mass found incidentally in an otherwise well child.
questions.hint: Also known as Wilms tumor.

questions.question: A 6 year old is brought to you with fever, bruising, easy fatigability and gum swelling. On examination she is pale and febrile, full hemogram shows neutrophilia. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: Signs of bone marrow failure (bruising, pallor) combined with gum swelling (infiltration) are highly suggestive of Acute Leukemia (specifically AML).
questions.hint: Gum hypertrophy is a specific sign of a type of blood cancer.

questions.question: A 8 year child is brought to you with history of fever and night sweats for 3 weeks now. On examination, there are cervical node swelling, and the child appears wasted. Which is the appropriate investigation for this child in this case?
questions.explanation: Cervical lymph node biopsy is definitive to distinguish between TB Adenitis and Lymphoma in persistent lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: You need tissue from the swelling to differentiate TB from cancer.

questions.question: A known child with epilepsy is brought to you with a history of prolonged convulsions taking 1 hour, on examination he is unconscious. What will be your first step?
questions.explanation: In any resuscitation (ABC), Airway and Breathing come first. Hypoxia is a major risk in status epilepticus.
questions.hint: ABC - Airway and Breathing first.

questions.question: A 4 year old weighing 15kgs is brought to you unconscious. He complained of headache, fever and convulsions. On examination you find neck stiffness, kerning sign positive. What drug and dose will you give?
questions.explanation: Meningitis treatment: Ceftriaxone 100mg/kg/day OD. 15kg * 100mg = 1500mg OD.
questions.hint: Calculate the daily dose of Ceftriaxone at 100mg/kg.

questions.question: A child is brought to you with history of delayed speech, he does not play with others, and he cannot withstand any changes in the environment. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: This triad (delayed communication, social isolation, restricted/repetitive behavior) is classic for Autism Spectrum Disorder.
questions.hint: Think of the condition characterized by social and communication deficits.

questions.question: A 10 year old is brought to you with pain in the lower limb. He attributes it to injury while playing, an x-rays shows reduced bone density and sunburst appearance. What is your impression?
questions.explanation: Sunburst appearance on X-ray is a pathognomonic sign of Osteosarcoma.
questions.hint: Sunburst pattern on X-ray.

questions.question: A child is rescued from a swimming pool. What will be the immediate cause of death?
questions.explanation: Hypoxemia (lack of oxygen) is the primary physiological insult in drowning that leads to cardiac arrest and death.
questions.hint: What is the primary lack in drowning?

questions.question: A 2 weeks old baby is brought to you because she is not breast feeding and is sleeping a lot. On examination she is febrile and weighs 4kgs. Which antibiotic regimen is the correct first-line treatment?

options.text: IV Ampicillin 200mg 12hrly and IV Gentamicin 12mg OD

questions.explanation: For neonatal sepsis, first-line treatment is IV Ampicillin (50mg/kg) + IV Gentamicin (3mg/kg). 4kg * 50mg = 200mg. 4kg * 3mg = 12mg.
questions.hint: Standard first-line for neonatal sepsis involves a Penicillin and an Aminoglycoside.

questions.question: A known asthmatic child is brought to you wheezing. On examination you find head nodding and cyanosis. Which of the following are immediate management steps? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: This is severe life-threatening asthma. Immediate O2, rapid bronchodilation (nebs), and steroids are required. Antibiotics are not routine unless infection is proven.
questions.hint: Treat the hypoxia, bronchospasm, and inflammation.

questions.question: A 4-year-old child with Severe Acute Malnutrition (MUAC 11cm, edema) is admitted. Which of the following are correct steps in the Stabilization Phase (Days 1-7)? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Prevent hypoglycemia with 10% Dextrose if needed

questions.explanation: Iron is withheld in stabilization (promotes bacterial growth). Standard ORS has too much sodium; ReSoMal is used. F-75, Antibiotics, and Hypoglycemia prevention are key steps.
questions.hint: Remember: No Iron, No high sodium fluids in the first phase.

questions.question: Match the investigation with the condition it helps rule out in a pale 3-year-old:
questions.explanation: BS checks for parasites. Stool checks for worms causing blood loss. Sickling test checks for HbS. BMA checks for malignancy.
questions.hint: Match the test to the specific pathology.

questions.question: A child diagnosed with Severe Malaria (convulsions, jaundice, severe anemia) is admitted. Which is the correct specific antimalarial drug and dose?

options.text: IV Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg (or 3mg/kg if <20kg) at 0, 12, 24 hours

questions.explanation: IV Artesunate is the gold standard for severe malaria. Quinine is never given as a bolus. Oral meds cannot be used initially in severe/unconscious cases.
questions.hint: The first-line parenteral drug given at 0, 12, and 24 hours.

questions.question: A 2-year-old presents unconscious with pinpoint pupils, frothing, and a chemical smell. What is the diagnosis and specific antidote?
questions.explanation: Pinpoint pupils and secretions (cholinergic crisis) indicate Organophosphate poisoning. Atropine is the antidote.
questions.hint: Cholinergic signs (wet lungs, small pupils) point to this agricultural chemical.

questions.question: A child with fever, arthralgia, and history of sore throat has joint tenderness. Diagnosed with Rheumatic Fever. What is the drug of choice for eradication of the causative organism?
questions.explanation: Benzathine Penicillin G is used to eradicate Group A Streptococcus and for long-term prophylaxis.
questions.hint: The standard long-acting penicillin injection.

questions.question: A 2-year-old presents with polyuria, polydipsia, dehydration, and acetone breath. What is the priority fluid management step?
questions.explanation: This is Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). Initial management involves fluid resuscitation with Normal Saline to restore perfusion.
questions.hint: Treat the shock/dehydration first with isotonic fluid.

questions.question: CASE STUDY: A 3-year-old is brought unconscious with history of 2 convulsions. He was previously treated for malaria. Examination: Unconscious, febrile, neck stiffness, positive Kernig's sign. Which of the following are correct management steps? (Select all that apply)

richContent.content:
Clinical Scenario:
A 3-year-old boy presents unconscious.
History: 2 convulsions at home. Treated for malaria recently.
Examination: Unconscious, Febrile, Neck stiffness (+), Kernig's sign (+).

options.text: Perform Lumbar Puncture (if no raised ICP signs) for CSF analysis

questions.explanation: The case is Bacterial Meningitis. Key steps: ABC resuscitation, LP for diagnosis, IV Ceftriaxone (high dose), and Dexamethasone (adjunct).
questions.hint: This is a medical emergency requiring admission, investigation for meningitis, and high-dose IV antibiotics.
